user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_try_alloc:
```c
void *
MHD_pool_try_alloc (struct MemoryPool *pool,
                    size_t size,
                    size_t *required_bytes)
{
  void *ret;
  size_t asize;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  asize = ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE (size);
  if ( (0 == asize) && (0 != size) )
  { /* size is too close to SIZE_MAX, very unlikely */
    *required_bytes = SIZE_MAX;
    return NULL;
  }
  if (asize > pool->end - pool->pos)
  {
    mhd_assert ((pool->end - pool->pos) == \
                ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->end - pool->pos));
    if (asize <= pool->end)
      *required_bytes = asize - (pool->end - pool->pos);
    else
      *required_bytes = SIZE_MAX;
    return NULL;
  }
  *required_bytes = 0;
  ret = &pool->memory[pool->end - asize];
  pool->end -= asize;
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (ret, size);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
*required_bytes = 0;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The function deliberately writes to required_bytes to return an out-parameter (assigning 0 as the required bytes), so the pointer must be modifiable and cannot be const-qualified. Therefore this use does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. (A violation would occur if the pointer were not modified but still declared non-const.)
